vampirism in dd is not something that can be done lightly or something you spring on your playersdm just because as such there are no rule by raw a to how to convert into a vampire the closest being becoming a vampire spawn which involves being slain by a true vampires bite attack and then buried by the next night the character will rise a a vampire spawn which will have a slight hindrance the player will lose their character forever since you are at the absolute control of the vampire and a such that character is considered dead and unplayable a vampire spawn can become a true vampire if they draw blood from their master but since you are under your master control they need to purposefully let you draw blood and there no way in hell a vampire would relinquish their power so easily theres also other plot driven extraordinary mean to do so like spoiler for curse of strahd the amber sarcophagus which let strahd become a vampire and a very powerful one at that and iirc he destroyed it afterwards so no one else could attain the same power then again the dm can come up with whatever they want to introduce attainable vampirism on their campaign just know that by design true vampirism is not meant to be attained by the player and a such you wont find rule about how it would work or what benefitshindrances would cause on the character the dhampir race would be the closest thing to a player having a vampireesque character everything else border on if they become a vampire they also become an npc and they need to roll a new character

grim hollow 3rd party ha some interesting mechanic for hero effected by vampirism lycanhropy etc basically once you get it you get a small boon if you choose to embrace it you level up and get a stronger boon but also a negative effect once you hit level 4 you are basically a full fledged vampire werewolf etc

after reading your extremely interesting post i thought id try to tackle the transition from the unicorn of literary folklore to the unicorn a a girl toy i came across a 2008 master thesis by deirdre pontbriand called unicorncopia the unicorn a collected object which ill be using a the main source for this post before getting to the modern stuff though i wanted to point out a few interesting bit about the earlier period first off her long list of european monarch pope and other aristocrat from the middle ages onward mostly confirms what youve said here  that collecting unicorn horn item wa something that mainly concerned the elite they were often fashioned into jewelled cup or sword hilt the belief that their horn had medicinal property led to them becoming a symbol of apothecary in the 17th and 18th century its in this way that the idea of a unicorn wa perhaps most familiar to those who were le wealthy pontbriand writes the visual association of the unicorn with the medicinal field disseminated and intensified belief in the animal among a wider demographic namely those who were not wealthy enough to posse a tusk of their own or an object made from it this belief wa reinforced by the powder and shaving taken from the tusk and dispensed by apothecary in the hope of curing innumerable ill once dutch and danish trader established trade with the greenland inuit in the 17th century narwhal tusk became much more widely available and were sometimes sold a a cheaper alternative to unicorn horn because of the christian association with the unicorn narwhal horn masquerading a unicorn horn were also occasionally available to pilgrim a relic the french abbey of saintdenis while generally quite an elite institution wa also a pilgrimage destination one of the attraction there wa the sixandahalffoot unicorn horn pilgrims would drink the water the horn wa washed in hoping for cure since the unicorn wa so closely linked to christ also of interest with regard to the danger of the unicorn  the medieval physiologus described the unicorn a a strong and fierce animal that could only be tamed by the virgin i couldnt find an english translation to read on the fly here but i found various place online that summarize it that way a pontbriand doe in her thesis the taming of the unicorn wa symbolically relevant because the unicorn wa considered to be otherwise quite dangerous and hard to catch ok moving on to modern stuff the 19th century and early 20th century are when you really start to see the transition of the unicorn from high culture to popular culture the lion and unicorn who began a serious heraldic symbol began to populate childrens book illustration such a the 1937 rex the coronation lion comes to town or 1911s jack and jill in this early stage they were still representing the lion and the unicorn of heraldic art but in a way that wa made cute for child unicorns were similarly included in walt disneys 1940 fantasia these unicorn were small and cute like the one in childrens book in the 1940s you could still find work like tennessee williamss the glass menagerie which called on unicorn symbolism a something to do with christian feminity and innocence but increasingly they were becoming associated a cute animal for child after that medievalist fantasy became deeply intertwined with the 1960s counterculture tolkien for example wa initially hugely popular with hippy renaissance faires were place where member of the 60 counterculture could get together and share idea a major meeting ground for beatnik in 1960s san francisco wa a coffeehouse called the blue unicorn the medieval religious aspect of the unicorn started to be secularized in the fantasy and countercultural zeitgeist medieval art like the unicorn tapestries were major source of artistic inspiration for these early mixing of fantasy nerd and the hippie counterculture a lot of the modern association we have with the unicorn started with the publication in 1968 of the last unicorn by peter s beagle beagle wa inspired by the unicorn tapestries which had been on display in the cloisters museum in the met in new york city since 1937 other inspiration included story and art hed consumed about unicorn a a child such a the colt from moon mountain by dorothy lathrop after the last unicorn wa adapted into an animated feature film in 1982 the book popularity exploded unicorns here were linked with medievalist fantasy and that association would never go away things started to get really weird in the 1980s oberon zellravenheart and morning glory were a married couple of hippy active in the 1980s in 1984 zellravenheart patented an operating technique for turning an angora goat into a unicorn it wa pretty grisly involving taking out the goat horn and transplanting them in a way that made it look like one horn they were inspired to do this by seeing the unicorn tapestries in the cloisters zellravenheart and glory made nine of these unicorn goat and toured them around renaissance faires in the united states in the 1980s they dressed a a wizard and enchantress and did performance with the unicorn in 1985 they leased four of the goat to the ringling brothers who presented the living unicorn attraction with them facsimiles of the medieval unicorn tapestries featured in all of these stunt the performance were widely mocked but helped cement the idea of the unicorn a a tacky 80 fantasy creature heres a quote from critic scott cummings in 1985 imagine botticellis birth of venus converted with disneylike innocence into a las vegasstyle halftime extravangaza in honor of the male sexual organ and what do you get the brith of penis  celebrate the fantasy say the ringmaster where myth becomes reality  standing in the center of a giant cold clamshell is the living unicorn and by his side a stunning blonde dressed like glynda the good witch  it is not the long spiral spike horn to be seen in the unicorn in captivity tapestry at the cloisters it is a large dull goat horn set off by the beast long and bushy white coat  the spectacle climax in a frenzy of pageantry elephants with goldandsilversequined unicorn tapestry on their back and feathered showgirl astride their neck lumber around the track  pinkandpurple zebrastriped centaur dressed like roman centurions pull chariot as the music crescendo sparkling coil spiral up out of low ionic column around the arena butterflygirls with iridescent wing waft overhead and the living unicorn now standing on a round dais in the center of the center ring slowly rise 10 in the air throughout the unicorn stare out with blank goatish complacency occasionally reaching back to scratch his hindquarter oblivious to the lavish phallic ritual going on in honor of his zoological oddity the unicorn in the 1980s wa caught up in a perfect storm fantasy wa still considered very kitsch and a niche interest but one with a thriving if socially marginalized subculture unicorns were associated with child especially girl and with nerd by the 1980s much of the bite of the 1960s countercultural movement had worn off and thing which had once been rather subversive symbol could be more easily commercialized unicorn toy became ubiquitous in the 1980s most famous of these is the my little pony lineup which included unicorn as you say in your post the association between girl and horse made the unicorn a natural choice for people marketing girl toy in the late 20th century lisa frank is another famous example of 80 and 90 supersaturated girly unicorn in conclusion id say that there is a thread of continuity when it come to the association between girl and unicorn from the medieval to the modern early fantasy writer were very inspired by medieval art and so the link between woman and the unicorn survived but the change from the formidable medieval beast to the cutesy tacky toy is down to late 20th century consumerism linking unicorn with the
